results.title: The Voice of the organ. No. 4
results.brief_description: Community hymn singing - hymns are sung by the choir of HMS Woolverstone whilst an unseen narrator encourages the audience to join in. The words are displayed on illustrated cards. At the organ, Fredric Bayco.

results.title: The Voice of Ivan Frost
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, Ann Shenfield, Robert Stephenson, Paul Fletcher and Alanya Van De Wiel
results.brief_description: In a surreal industrial landscape populated by equally bizarre characters, the magical voice of celebrated singer Ivan Frost has the power to make people wish for death. In a remote village elsewhere, Alfonso Pellegrini, a shepherd with an astonishing musical talent, longs to leave his sheep and go in search of the fabulous sounds described in books. Being invited to play beside the remarkable singer, Alfonso is saddened to find himself thrust into the background, his precious violin broken from trying to compete for attention. Ivan’s world is similarly turned upside down when he awakens to find his voice gone and a scar across his chest. Without his legendary voice to bewitch the masses and open doors for him, he is forced to confront the nightmarish reality of his situation - alone.

results.title: The Voice in the fingers
results.brief_description: Introduces Highland music in its natural and historical environment. Shows the different types of this music and its impact on the music outside Scotland.

results.title: The Vital signs and their inter-relation: body temperature, pulse, respiration, blood pressure
results.creator_credit: Willard Pictures and United States. Office of Education. Division of Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
A study of the physiology of the respiratory, heat regulatory, and circulatory systems, and their inter-relation in normal functioning, as well as in deviations from the normal. How to ascertain and record the vital signs, the importance of making thorough and accurate observations, and how to take care of the apparatus necessary for these observations, is demonstrated.
Designed for use in the instruction of professional nurses.

results.title: The Vital link
results.creator_credit: Rank Audio Visual, M.J. Clark and W. J. Allen
results.brief_description: Examines the development of transport routes, how the preferred means of transport is usually a compromise between convenience, speed and cost and some of the problems caused by an ever increasing dependence on transport in our everyday lives.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rank Audio Visual, M.J. Clark and W. J. Allen

results.title: The Visitor from California = Jia Zhou Lai Ke
results.creator_credit: Nanhai Film Company and Liu Guanxiong
results.brief_description:
Synopsis:
Annie comes from California and is in China for her PhD research on Chinese women. A Chinese-American, Annie went to his father’s hometown in Guangdong and became interested in the experience of a local factory director, Ms Mei. Annie found that although Ms Mei was so capable and successful as the director of a large factory, her love life was not happy. Her husband went overseas to seek fortune shortly after their marriage and Ms Mei had heard nothing from her husband for more than 30 years. Although Ms Mei was not even sure whether her husband was alive or dead, she treated her disabled mother-in-law as her own mother and kindly adopted an abandoned child. Ms Mei struggled between love and traditional values for women when a local school teacher fell in love with her. Ms Mei eventually did not take the step for love and firmly opposed to her daughter’s divorce when the young couple’s relation had problem. Annie’s parents were on way to China to see Annie, and the fact that Annie’s father had the same name as Ms Mei’s ex husband disturbed Mei a lot. It turned out that Ms Mei’s ex husband died on boat on his voyage to the US, and he gave his valuable passport (not everybody had one) to Anne’s father, who was the few survived and had used Ms Mei’s husband’s name after arriving in the US. Annie and her parents went back to the America and Ms Mei decided to start a new life.

Cultural History of the Film:
Nanhai Film Corporation is a film company based in Beijing. It produces both films and TV series.
China adopted the “open-door” policy in the late 1970s, and since then, overseas Chinese were able to (re)-visit China, where they sometimes experienced a “cultural shock”. Guangdong and Fujian (aka. Canton and Hokian) are the two provinces which had the largest number of emigrants living overseas.

Researcher’s Comments:
This film adopts a westerner’s perspective to examine the changes taking place both in Chinese people’s mind and society in the early 1980s. It deals with the conflicts of traditional and new values from a foreigner’s point of view, which is not uncommon in Chinese cinema.

(3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; May 21, 2010)
